Award.AwardTitle: Monoidal Categories and Categorification in Classical Representation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Groups are fundamental mathematical objects that arise in the study of symmetry. Some of the most important and universal examples include symmetric groups, which arise from symmetries of finite sets, and general linear groups, which arise from symmetries of finite-dimensional vector spaces; both of these examples are a particular focus for this project. Classical representation theory studies groups (and related algebras) by focusing on how they act on other mathematical objects, such as topological spaces. Informally, a representation is a snap-shot of the underlying group (or algebra) taken from a particular vantage point. In the last decade or so, the idea of categorification has become extremely important in this general area and has led to the development of what is now known as higher representation theory. This involves actions of groups on mathematical structures called categories, utilizing not only the relations between these structures (functors) but also relations between these relations (natural transformations). It is a burgeoning area with many applications inside and outside of mathematics, including finite group theory, ring theory, combinatorics, Lie theory, category theory, representation theory, knot theory, and even computer science and theoretical physics.

This project will study some important and rich categories appearing in representation theory arising from symmetric groups, general linear groups, and related Lie algebras and Lie superalgebras. The project reflects the recent trend towards higher representation theory. There is special emphasis on monoidal categories and categorical Kac-Moody actions. At the same time, the project is firmly rooted in important classical problems in representation theory, such as Broue's Abelian Defect Group Conjecture for finite groups, and the study of maximal subgroups of finite simple groups. Several parts of the project are concerned with the study of derived equivalences between blocks of naturally occurring categories in representation theory, and exploit braid group actions on derived categories. One part of the project is of a more foundational nature, developing the general theoretical framework of highest weight categories in a new direction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This award has supported research on some important and rich categories appearing in representation theory arising from symmetric groups, general linear groups, and related Lie algebras and Lie superalgebras. Specifically, the PI has made significant progress in understanding the connection between Heisenberg and Kac-Moody categorifications (joint with Savage and Webster). This work revisits many classical examples putting them into a common framework of Heisenberg categorification, and is the culmination of 20 years of work by many researchers on this type of categorification.  Also in this period of support, the co-PI has completed the classification of the irreducible restrictions of representations of symmetric and alternating groups to subgroups (joint with Morotti and Tiep). This achievement builds on more than three decades of research activity going back to seminal work of Saxl (1987) in characteristic zero, and is a crucial part of the Aschbacher-Scott program on maximal subgroups of finite classical groups.


2. BROADER IMPACTS

The award has had a substantial educational impact through the training of graduate students and mentoring other young researchers.  The PI has mentored G. Webb and M. Vargas, and the co-PI has mentored D. Steinberg, D. Bursa and I. Weinschelbaum, during this period.
The PI and co-PI have also been collaborating on writing a graduate level algebra textbook, which currently exists in a preprint form and has been piloted at the University of Oregon and Rutgers University.
Both have been actively involved in knowledge dissemination nationally and internationally, including invited lectures, masterclasses and lecture series for graduate students and young mathematicians throughout the world. For example, the co-PI was a speaker at the "Connections for women: group representation theory and applications" conference at MSRI and the PI gave a lecture series at an introductory workshop at MSRI, both in 2018. The award has also indirectly support the promotion of knowledge through the active involvement of the PI and co-PI as editors of leading research journals: Journal of Algebra and Applications (PI), Algebraic Combinatorics (PI), Advances in Mathematics (co-PI), Journal of Combinatorial Algebra (co-PI) and Transformation Groups (co-PI). Finally this award has supported the PI and co-PI in organizing conferences: the PI has organized a BIRS-Oaxaca conference "Algebraic and geometric categorification" (2019) and an AMS special session "Monoidal categories in representation theory" (2020), and the co-PI has served on the program committees for the "Lie algebras, algebraic groups, and invariant theory" summer schoolds held in Russia (2018—present), and has been an organizer of the  2018 MSRI semester program "Representation theory of groups".
